<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_get_timestamp:
```c
unsigned long long metal_get_timestamp(void)
{
	unsigned long long t = 0;
	struct timespec tp;
	int r;

	r = clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &tp);
	if (r == -1) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "clock_gettime failed!\n");
		return t;
	}
	t = tp.tv_sec * (NS_PER_S);
	t += tp.tv_nsec;

	return t;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_get_timestamp:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The macro itself does not directly call metal_get_timestamp, so there is no definite self-call in the shown code. However an indirect recursion scenario exists: if _metal.common.log_handler is set to point to metal_get_timestamp (or to any function that eventually calls metal_get_timestamp), then metal_get_timestamp -> metal_log (expands to call log_handler) -> metal_get_timestamp would produce an indirect self-call and thus violate Rule 17.2. Similarly, if metal_fmt() or the log handler calls metal_log/metal_get_timestamp back, indirect recursion can occur.
